attributes.Title: Neurotechnology
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Neuroscience & Behavior
321TC
Mount Holyoke College
Recently, the development of novel technologies for probing neurobiological questions has proceeded at a dizzying pace. This course focuses on three broad fields in neurotechnology: optical methods for examining neural activity and structures, innovations in electrophysiology, and mind-machine interfaces. Specific topics may include: optogenetics, 2-photon microscopy, 'brainbow' imaging, methods for single ion channel recording, and neuroprosthetics. Presentation, discussion, and critique of research articles will form the core of the course. As a culminating experience, students will write mock grant proposals for experimentation based on techniques discussed in class.
Prereq: Biological Sciences 220.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
91054,91150
91150

95655

attributes.Title: The Neurobiology of Stress
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Neuroscience & Behavior
309ST
Mount Holyoke College
In this seminar, students will gain a thorough understanding of the stress response system, referred to as the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis. Using primary literature, the course will cover various facets of the HPA axis, including the cellular and anatomical neuroscience behind the stress response. Students will gain an understanding of the techniques commonly used to assess acute and chronic HPA axis activity and behavioral reactivity in humans and in a variety of non-human animals. We will explore how genes and the environment interact to determine how an individual will respond to a stressor and examine irregular activity of the HPA axis in neuropsychiatric disorders, including Anxiety, Depression, and Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder.
This course is offered to neuroscience majors only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

95018

attributes.Title: Intro to Neuroscience
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Neuroscience & Behavior
100
Mount Holyoke College
This comprehensive survey course explores the brain and the biological basis of behavior. We will examine the anatomy of the nervous system and the unique properties of the cells that make up the brain. We will discuss the mechanisms by which individual brain cells communicate with each other, and how small networks of cells underlie more complex processes such as perception, learning, and behavior. In labs, students will perform experiments that expand upon and reinforce these ideas through hands-on exercises.
This course is limited to first-year students.; Coreq:  NEURO-100L.
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Biology of Neuro Diseases
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Neuroscience & Behavior
330
Mount Holyoke College
Biology of Neurological Diseases will explore the molecular and cellular basis of neurological diseases.  We will investigate the biological mechanisms underlying neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer's disease.  We will focus on animal models used to investigate pathogenic mechanisms and the biology underlying therapeutic strategies.  This class will rely heavily on primary research articles and in-class discussions.
Prereq: Biological Sciences 210, Biological Sciences 220 and Psychology 250 or Neuroscience 100.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
91151

attributes.Title: Cellular and Molecular Neuro.
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Neuroscience & Behavior
324
Mount Holyoke College
This course will explore cellular and molecular mechanisms of nervous system development and function through lectures, laboratory exercises, and the critical analysis of primary literature.  Topics include synapse formation and synaptic transmission, neuronal-glial interactions, the molecular basis of behavior, and applied genetic engineering techniques.
Prereq: Neuroscience 100 and Biological Sciences 220
This course meets the 300-level laboratory-based course requirement for the Neuroscience and Behavior major.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
